Spider-Man: Miles Morales does whatever a Spider can. Literally. You swing around punching people and using gadgets just like in the first game. I might criticize this game for being too similar. Certainly in a head to head competition, the first game is going to win. It’s simply bigger and also the first time you see this version of New York. Yet Miles Morales is a fantastic game in its own right and for that it deserves credit. Even if this were an expansion, it would be a fantastic expansion and I would score it the same. Let’s address the rhinoceros in the room. This game is short but not too short. My playthrough took 17 hours. I liked that the game was short. The game does not hit you with upgrade paths that require a lot of grinding or an insane amount of collectibles needed for a new costumes or a Platinum trophy. Every minute of my 17 hours was spectacular. The magic of the game is the gameplay. All of the cutscenes, performances, and story elements are nice. I’ve played games with great cutscenes and terrible gameplay and one of them is The Order: 1886. I’ve also played games with great gameplay and terrible cutscenes and one of those is Just Cause 2. Either one will only take a game so far. Combine both and you have a legend. If you have played the first Spider-Man game, you know what to expect with Miles Morales. A short thought on Miles Morales, his powers fit right into a video game because they are OP as hell. Think about it. He has all of the original Spider-Man’s powers and Spider-Man already has a complete power set. On top of all that, Miles Morales can become invisible and shoot out electricity. This means that in a tough fight, Miles can go invisible like a get of danger free card. Or he can use his electricity powers like a win button. Writing for Miles Morales must be a chore, because like with Super-Man in the DC Universe, Miles is assured of winning so long as he uses all of his powers. In a video game, though, going invisible and hitting bad guys with electricity is plainly and simply fun to do. Miles fits right in. The last time I played a stand-alone expansion like this was Infamous: First Light. I believe that expansion was made by the same studio. The difference between First Light and Miles Morales is that I downloaded First Light for free with PS+ and I paid $50 for Miles Morales. I will stay out of the debate of weather Miles Morales is a good deal. I usually wait a year or more to buy games and in fact I bought the complete Spider-Man game a year late for a mere $25. Sony is certainly making a case for the value of Miles Morales by including a PS5 version of first Spider-Man game as a $20 add-on. Best not to get into the value debate. A good game is good regardless of playtime and price. Last thought on this game: I want more of it. Keeping my fingers crossed for a Spider-Man 2 with two spider-men.

Miles Morales has some big shoes to fill in the follow up to 2018’s satisfying delivery of Spider-Man at last on modern consoles. The good news is that we really do get Spider-Man: Miles Morales, possibly the best of both worlds. The graphics are eye-catching. Webswinging through the city and scaling buildings allows for some excellent panoramic views. The game also suffers from what is looking like a next-gen issue, in that we must make a choice between resolution and framerate. For me, framerate wins all the time. I spent a good 90% of my time in performance modes and the difference was amazing for me. The smoothness and fluidity of movement on-screen makes the game all the more enjoyable. The only thing I would like to have seen is more variety in the suits. The game is quite ‘forward-looking’, as I’m guessing these suits are mostly from the comics as I didn’t recognize most of them. Then we have the gameplay, where MM has a particular focus and a solid foundation from the first Spider-Man game. What I really liked here is that they were able to build upon this to avoid repetition and rehashing the same 2018 mechanics. At first the Venom mechanics seemed annoying to me, but with practice they prove their usefulness and establish MM with his own identity. It’s quite enjoyable having the powers to smash through heavy shields, for example. Let’s not forget the key component of any Spider-Man game – webswinging.I don’t think we’ve ever seen better mechanics for this until 2018, but now MM is able to build on this also to make it very responsive and definitely the best webswinging I think you’ll ever experience. The biggest downside of the gameplay is that the repetition is still there. They tried to amp-up the mission varieties and include a nifty app for accessing them, but you still get a lot of the dreaded Ubisoft mentality where the map can be littered with things to collect and mini-missions that can get tedious. Fortunately, these are largely optional and doing them sparingly does provide a break from the main story. I think most people will be glad to know Mary Jane’s stealth missions are absent here, and the camouflage mechanic made stealth a whole lot more appealing, whereas the last game made just want to crash in and maul everyone to be faster. Lastly, the story. MM attempts to convey a very modern story; the characters are diverse and not necessarily white American-born. More importantly, the story conveys well the sense of community that the first game touched upon with the homeless shelter. MM tends to be a very likeable if unremarkable character. I was quite surprised that only Rhino makes an appearance from the OG bad guys, but this also makes sense to avoid repetition. Really, the game and plot have their own identity to the point that everyone’s presence made sense, so I don’t think any mainstream villains would have added much to the story. Overall, Spider-Man: Miles Morales worried me that it would be more like a DLC than a standalone game, but it’s not and I really enjoyed the game. There is some repetition and occasional monotony when the pacing slows, but this seemed to add to the whole experience. It’s not the longest game, but that’s not a bad thing to me. While it borders on cliché, Miles Morales is a welcome addition to the Spider-Man videogame catalogue and I am very intrigued to see where they go from here.

Spiderman MM is definitely a great superhero game and it does a lot to improve on its predecessor in terms of combat and traversal. It never really gets old to web-sling through an accurate depiction of New-York City. The story and gameplay was enjoyable enough for me to at least want a gameplay session in everyday. The story had likeable characters (shoutout OG Spiderman specifically) and not one really stood out to me as a bad character. Graphics are amazing and as expected from a launch title for the PS5. However, the game did miss two marks for me. One big gripe I had with the game was the overall playtime. If we disregard side missions and the open-world activities, we are looking at 6-7 hours of main mission playtime, which bothered me for a triple A open-world $100 (AUS) game. It also does not help that the first game doubles this playtime. Another issue I could not look over was the lack of memorable boss fights, its hard not to compare it to the first game but, the first game did have many good boss fights against OG Spiderman’s iconic villains. This game did not even reach to half of that. Although, the final boss was a banger. Overall, it is pretty difficult to justify paying full price for this game, but I can say that it is game that should not be looked over, especially if you were a fan of the first game. miles morale review After loving and enjoying Spider-Man (2018) I was excited to play my PS5 Launch game Spider-Man: Mile Morales. From the momoent I fired it up, I was a little confused by the textures.  Lighting seemed decent, but textures looked lower quality than I expected.  I instantly went to youtibe and searched Miles morales ps5 vs ps4 and found some compatison videos showing graphical differences, and was horrified to see they were identical across 7 year old platforms. After playing a large amount for mile morales ultimate digitally  I was rally dissapinted that I was getting a ps4 quality game which I couldn't played without getting a ps5. Aside from that, mile morales is extremely similar to the previous Spiderman game.  Everything is very a cookie-cutter copy of the previous game, aside from ney work being the same, the enamies are blatant reskins of the same enemies of the previous game.  Very little seems new.Miles is obviously fairly similar being spiderman, but has a lot less gagdets.  The main difference is that Miles has camoflage.  Additionally the enemy difficulty seems harder than with the previous game, it takes a lot more punch to take down enemies (yet the boss attles seem much easier in this game).  I found the most enjoyable experience for me was just to turn the game into a stealth game and constantly be camoflage, and stealth takedown everyone. So aside froma graphically dissapointing reskin of Spider-Man (2018) with camgoflage, there's obvious a new story that revolves around Miles.  However for some reason this is very short, the story is much shorter than the previous game.  I hit 50% completed in a few hours.That being said, I really didn't find the story of the game that interesting.  The relationship with the uncle was the only thing I was somewhat intersted in, and it was very briefly told.  The mother character is barely in the game, the friend is a thinly developed character.  The lead girl is thinly developed.  The rest of the enemies get very little screen time.  Peter is obviously very barely in it (although i found the times he was present far more interesting the Miles, miles is a pretty 2 dimentional character).  The very ending was fairly redeeming though. I tried to space out the story missions to make the game last longer once i started to see how short it is, but there's very few side missions.  There's only a dozen or so of each collectable, so they're fast to collect.  The crime around the city seems to be sparce, many districts have no crime or side quests, andd the ones that do only seems to trigger crime events very rarely.The main new side-mission format is the in-game spiderman app.  However this only provides about a dozen little missions that are very quick to complete (~5 minutes per quest). There's also a sort of series of side quests to identify and record sounds around the city to make music.  Whilst this is a fairly unique idea, I found it really out of place and incredibly dull.  Also again, quick to complete. Another thing to mention is the sound.  I found the music pretty dull, I like hip-hop style music, but this was quite bland, and missed the soundtrack from the previous game.  Also the radio/podcasts were far fewer in this game than the previous, and the new primary podcast host Danicka was very uninteresting. I know there's a lot of online buzz about how buggy the game is and how miles gets repalced by random objects such as street lamps and trash bins etc.  I didn't experience this but maybe that particular bug has been fixed now.I have however had a cuple of minor crashes, and one big one that completey locked up my game, and eventually hut down the entire ps5.  After a while struggling to get the ps5 to turn on again, and me thinking it was dead forever, it came back up.  This funnily enough occured during the final battle of the game.nasty crash. Honestly, Spider-man: Miles Morales felt more like a dlc than a full game.  The game I just played previous to this was Far Cry: Primal.  Which coincidentally was originally going to be a DLC for Far Cry 4, until Ubisoft decided to turn it into a standalone game.  Whilst I'm not the biggest fan of Far Cry: Primal.  I spent about 30 hours to complete it.  Spider-man: Miles Morales took me about 12, which included unlocking everything. (I choose not to do New Game plus as the game wasn't that enjoyable the first time around).

Every moment fun and exciting.  Collecting and powering up suits, takedown animations, the fun combat from the previous game and a easy interface for all the side missions were my favorite highlights of the game.  The pacing was great and the cutscenes did a good job of Not dragging on.

When I first began playing Miles Morales, I was worried I would not like the game at all. It was very clear from the beginning this game was intended as an standalone DLC-Game (ex. Infamous First Light, Uncharted Lost Legacy, etc), and with how heavily the assets were reused from the world map even down to certain enemy encounters I was shaking my head very early on. However, to write this off as simply a 'glorified DLC' would be a cruel injustice to a very fun game. Spider-Man Miles Morales is a delightful journey of a young man finding his walk in life, deciding what's write and wrong along the way. While the plot of the game is easily predictable, the character development he goes through during the events of the story matter so much more. This game finally made me like Miles as a character, because through playing this story I was able to find out not only what his character was like, but what he wanted it to be. Along the way you meet all sorts of delightful characters like his mother, uncle, and even an adorable deaf girl who really round out the city of Harlem. Gameplay wise it's more or less the same as the original, but Miles does play very differently than Peter which makes fighting a whole new experience (and he doesn't quite have Pete's finesse, so even web slinging is delightful). And of course in truest Insomniac fashion, the game is just as flashy and fun to watch as it is to play during their wonderful cutscenes complimented by excellent actors. Oh! And music too! I may not be much for rap, but they nailed it for me in this game. I can continue to sing this game's praises, but I have to voice a couple more grievances as well. While I think everyone who enjoyed the first game should play this game, I cannot suggest paying more than 20 dollars for it, certainly no more than 30. While I do believe the effort put into this game justifies the standalone release, the amount of reused assets do not justify a 50 dollar price tag, especially with the game being so short at less than 6 hours if you're not trying for a complete file. What's more, if you ARE a completionist, they force you into a NG+ to unlock things and get the Platinum trophy. I love Insomniac to death but I think there were a few missteps here, especially with their marketing. Honestly though, while I complain about some of these things, they simply do not take away from an absolutely amazing game. It is an absolute thrill from beginning to end and is filled with so many fun characters and good feels it makes everything else seem superficial. In spite of my problems with pricing models and reused assets, I still cannot see this game as anything less than an amazing game. If you enjoyed the original, do continue on this journey because it is an incredible one. Just... as affordably as possible.

What a game to introduce the PS5 to! From the moment the game started, I immediately new that I was in for a treat. The PS5 quick loading and impressive framerate, graphics, etc., make this game a true gem. The duelsense remote added another layer to the immersivity of the whole experience. As for Miles, Nadji Jeter completely encapsulated who Miles was and how he was able to discover his own Spider-Man. There's something that Nadji does that makes Miles feel so relatable and lovable; therefore, making him my favourite depiction of Spider-Man to date. My online criticism (which is a really selfish one) is that I wanted this game to last forever; which really isn't a criticism, as I understand why it is the length that it is. This is not a Spider-Man 2 videogame, it is a game on its own standard that desired to stand out and distinguish itself from the first Spidey game...and that it does. Regardless, I loved every moment of this game and I cannot wait to play it again. Great job to the entire team at Insomniac for creating this gem!!!

Miles Morales takes the original Spider-Man, changes a few details, adds in a couple of new powers to play around with, then calls it a day. If the original had been on PC, what you get in MM could be done in a simple mod, sans the story mode cut scenes and voice-overs. Further, the story seems to use the original game as a blueprint for its emotional beats, similar to how Star Wars Episode VII mirrored the original movie (episode IV).That's not to say this game is bad. If you've never played the original, you will likely be blown away. If you have played the original and enjoyed it, you'll find more of the same. There are just enough new things to deal with to keep your interest.But as other reviews point out, that's because the game is relatively short. In fact, I get the feeling that the developers knew this going in, as a number of skills, upgrades, and even a trophy are all locked behind New Game+. Not a great sign if you are looking for a game with a lot of content.In summary: It's a lot like the original, just a few tweaks, none of which are bad. Is it a good game? Yes. Is it worth slobbering over like so many critics are doing? No. In fact, if you've played the original, you can probably save a few bucks by waiting for a price drop (this is a first party published game).

Marvel's Spider-Man: Miles Morales (henceforth MSMM) is a great continuation of the Marvel's Spider-Man game released in 2018 on PS4. MSMM's 8-hours-long main plot follows Miles Morales on his journey to prove himself worthy of being Spider-Man. Likeable characters include Miles' mother Rio Morales and uncle Aaron Davis. Roxxon's Simon Krieger is a forgettable bad guy. Phin Mason is a female version of the Tinkerer aka Phineas Mason, with the intent to highlight more obscure villains from Spider-Man's rogue gallery, but actually this version screams of SJW agenda and forced diversity BS. This female character is likeable but should have been named as someone else. Even creating a new character for the game (just like the Arkham Knight in the eponymous game) would have been a better idea. But as the Tinkerer, Phin Mason just doesn't cut it. Sony and Insomniac Games made the controversial decision to change Peter Parker's face with a new actor's likeness, closer to that of Hollywood actor Tom Holland. Some people like the change, others hate it, I am somewhere in the middle. Gameplay is the same as it was in 2018's Marvel's Spider-Man. It's an open world where you traverse by slinging from bulding to building. Combat is still very smooth and sublime, topping even the combat system of the Batman Arkham games. Miles Morales comes equipped with a few extra powers relative to Peter Parker, namely venom (bio-electric) attacks and invisibility, just like in the comics. This game takes advantage of the Dualsense controller's haptic feedback, but its implementation is way more subtle than Astro's Playroom's excellent showcase. MSMM is a smaller-scale stand-alone game in the style of inFamous: First Light and Uncharted: The Lost Legacy. It was developed by Insomniac Games in 2 years in order to coincide with PS5's launch while also releasing on PS4. On PS5 the game features all the next gen bells and whistles such as ridiculously fast loading times and multiple graphical modes. The game originally launched with 2 graphical modes, Fidelity (4K, 30 fps and Ray Tracing) and Performance (1440p, 60 fps, no Ray Tracing). In the weeks following launch Insomniac Games managed to add via patch a 3rd mode named RT Performance which combines Ray Tracing and 60 fps with a few compromises in RT's settings and a lower resolution (something closer to 1080p than 1440p). No matter what mode you select image quality is excellent and the game plays great, but I recommend playing with the new RT Performance mode. The only objective downside to this game is its nature of being a quick project designed to launch with the PS5. Developers understandably had to reuse assets and code from the original game in order to speed up development, but the game doesn't feel that fresh when compared with the 2018 game. Other than that, I disapprove of a few minor SJW agenda references put in the game. I've had enough of this forced BS in recent years. As of posting, MSMM costs quite a lot of money for what is a 8 hours-long game (maybe 12-15 hours with all side content). Currently this game isn't good value for money, but in the future when the price will have dropped to 20 dollars/euros it will be a great deal. Currently MSMM (as well as Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered) is plagued by bugs. My PS5 crashed 2 times (thankfully there was no hardware issue and no save file was lost, problem was solved with a restart) while playing, so hopefully Sony and Insomniac Games will release patches both for the console's OS and the game's code in the near future. Overall, Marvel's Spider-Man: Miles Morales is an enjoybale game that also showcases some of the PS5's potential. I recommend this game to everyone.

Miles Morales is another great hit by Insomniac team, they nailed the narrative, characters, visuals and gameplay. It’s a game about social/cultural diversity and representativity brought to a universe of a beloved super hero in a videogame. It’s a game about living in community and respect for each other. It’s a game about self-learning and understanding how to self-accept. An approach that is important nowadays and something that we need to see more often in videogames. All of the aforementioned characteristics of this game are expressed by the many great characters and how the narrative unfolds between them, either by doing the main quest or side quests. Alongside the well written narrative, the performance of actors/voice actors are top notch with a well-done animation too. Yes, it is not a long game, you can complete the main quest within a few hours, but you’ll probably want to do all the other things like side quests, challenges or just explore the gorgeous New York city in winter. This will take a few dozen hours more. And it’s definitively worth it. This game is visually impressive on PS5. Seeing the ray traced reflections of the buildings while you swing around the streets of New York with a buttery smooth 60 fps is simply amazing. The ray tracing reflection is just not about visuals, but also helps with awareness of the environment and enemies. And talking about awareness, this game also does a great use of the 3d audio (tempest engine), it adds depth and precise placement of the sounds, making it one of the most immersive city that I ever heard in a game. Don’t forget to turn this option on in your PS5. Another technically impressive achievement is the absence of loadings time. It’s so good to jump into the game with almost no waiting time or to fast travel in a blink of an eye. Regarding gameplay, Mile Morales uses the same great mechanics found in 2018 Marvel’s Spider-Man. Miles performs swings with more acrobatics and have his own set of abilities. The combats still fun and traversing through the city is always very pleasant. I just think they could use the adaptative triggers and haptics of DualSense in a more profound way. It’s an OK application. In summary, this is an excellent spin-off to the Marvel’s Spider-Man franchise. All that you loved in the 2018 game is also in Miles Morales. It’s a PS5 must have. And I hope that Insomniac Studios keep up with their great work.

Awesome ! Let it be known I have not played the Ps4 version yet (Amazing Spiderman) If you haven't played either... Well.. Miles looks and feels amazing.  If you have a high end 4k HDR TV, playing the game at 30 FPS is actually really nice, but you can swap to 60 for framerate.  The game looks beautiful.  A lot of the Quick time events, or story missions, seem to render at a higher quality (Think first 15 minutes of Last of Us) and it's incredible. Thoughts: I don't play a lot of single player game, nor do I beat a whole lot either but two titles that i found extremely fun and worth my time is Infamous: Second Son and Miles Morales.  There's a lot of quick time events, but they are fun and exciting.  It takes place around Christmas time so you get to swing through a snowy NYC.  This adds an extra touch considering there will be a lot of gamers playing this on Christmas Day. Strengths.  Gameplay, it's smooth.  Think Batman basically.  Swinging though the city is easy and feels extremely rewarding when done properly.  It's so much fun to run up a sky scraper and swing in-between building.  The game environment (City) looks amazing.  You will be amazed when climbing the Empire State and looking over an seeing all the building in high detail! I like how easy it is to do side missions.  They pop up on the ingame phone app and spawn randomly when you are close by.  I also enjoy collecting the "Time capsules".  Fun lore. My biggest con is lack of boss battles.  I think there's 3 in total but it feels about 1.  Story could be better?  It's over the top.  I don't think it was necessary.  The collecting of the sounds clip is an interesting mechanic but felt like it took me away from my game, or at least really slowed me down when I was trying to progress. Story:  Basically a love story with good and bad undertones.  The ending is a bit of the top.  There's a twist or two and were enjoyed. Characters: Are ok.  I am not a huge fan of Miles but he's a good hero who always does the right thing.  His relationship with the female protagonist is interesting. Movement: Smooth and fun.  No real complaints.  Swinging is a blast, combat is great. Extras: Challenges, Time Capsules (Collecting), Collecting the sound samples, Crime and other tasks done by the in-game app P.S.  Giving a game a low score because it is short is a terrible way to bring down a rating. Price and Time doesn't make a game a good or bad.  That's more of an issue of investment.  I would feel more comfortable spending $50 considering Amazing Spider man is a Ps4 title, and there is a short campaign (but it's packed) and was a launch title.  This won't be effecting my score as it shouldn't.

Spider-Man Miles Morales is a good game. Short and sweet, while not being a major improvement over its previous entry. One thing that I want to get out of the way first: The graphics are gorgeous!The first Spider-Man game, on base PS4, already looked amazing, but this is definitely the most significant improvement over the original.And not only it looks good, it also plays great! Swinging around the city is still a joy, the fast-paced combat system continues to excel expectations and unlockables like new suits, gadgets and skills feel very rewarding. The story is also great. While not as involving as the original game, I felt like Miles' story is much more personal, with freedom to take the character into different and more original paths than the ones we've already seen in other Spider-Man media. Great voice performances, exciting action moments and emotional cuts make this game worth picking up. What hurts this game, in my opinion, is the lack of novelty.A few things that I did not like in the original are still here. And since this is a much shorter experience, these things just get in the way of a great story being told.Side quests are still repetitive, but this time they don't add anything cool to flesh out the Spider-Man mythos, like the previous game did with some of them. The lack of enemy variety is sad and in harder difficulties, they still take forever to die.And the worst thing in the entire game: THE PUZZLES!They get old quick. Basically, they turn Miles Morales into a walking "generator energy". It's absurd! This game is very short, so buying it at full price might not be the best idea, but if/when you do pick it up, you'll definitely have a great time, whether you're a Spider-Man fan or just a sucker for good Action Adventure games.Now, if you've played the old one, you'll probably reach the credits with the taste of an overglorified DLC, in your mouth...

Marvel's Spider-Man: Miles MoralesThe exaggerated swagger of a young black teenIs it a full game is it not a full game, this is the question.. nd the answer is.. no…I don’t care what anyone says… Miles morales is a 6 hour long expansion to 2018’s spiderman, theres nothing wrong with that.. but that’s what it is and feels as such.. more of the same, though this time you play through the very rushed story of Miles Morales, who is left with New York city in his hands to take care of while the og spiderman goes to hangout with his boo. Obviously there are tons of collectables and pretty okay sidequests to do around this 6 hour long story, but since it feels like more of the same.. I didn’t care too much to do what felt like, heres more content patched into that game you really loved 2 years ago… though to mix things up, miles morales feels more like batman mixed with spiderman, and I love that, my favorite moments of the arkham games is lurking in the shadows and just snatching fools up, and its just as satisfying here to clear a room without engaging in combat.. and I was mostly pushed towards that because sadly the combat just isn’t satisfying here, don’t get me wrong, it stylish and flashing, you feel like a true hero when you pull off perfect combos, and you alredy know the swagger is exaggerated, but the enemies feel like sponges stopping miles mroales from feeling as satisfying as it could.. which again kept me away from doing too much side activites, im either going to be suffering through the spongey combat, or im going to be doing some dragged out puzzle of connecting electricity with my web…Miles Morales is definitely a great game, with great characters, its beautiful, the music is amazing, and it tells a really touching story, but this is really just a really well put together expansion… no matter what anyone says.but with that being said, it’s a great expansion to an amazing game, one with mechanics that feel smooth, the most fun open world outside of an assassins creed gameAnd with its own platinfum trophy and the $20 discount, I guess that’s okay.I give Marvel's Spider-Man: Miles Moralesan 8/10

I found myself very disappointed with story and characters, they're not nearly as gripping and fleshed out in my opinion and the side missions and activities are just as middling and repetitive as they were in the 2018 game. Peter Parker already felt generic as a protagonist, but was elevated through an amazing support cast. Miles Morales is even more boring and this time, the side characters and antagonists don't even carry their own weight. But it's not like you really get to form some kind of emotional bond with them, because everything is so rushed and shallow. The game loves to throw the player in the middle of things without properly introducing or explaining them and to me it always felt like I was missing hours of content / context, which caused the plot "twists" to simply not work at all. But aside from its awful writing, Miles Morales is an okay experience overall in terms of gameplay. Unless you're a big fan of the comics or *really* want more Insomniac Spider-Man though, you're not missing out on much if you skip this one.

Combat includes new moves and possibilities, while traversal has different animations to fit the new character. Many costumes and perks create interesting combinations, but it can get repetitive by the very end (specially if you played the first one recently). SOUNDTRACK: even better than the first one, more personalized with a urban style. The game runs perfectly on PS5, with minimal loading times and a graphical mode that includes both RTX and 60fps. Lo Mismo. Pero Para Mal. JUGABILIDAD:Este juego causó mucho revuelo por haber sido concebido como una aventura totalmente nueva y no como una expansión jugable, y ceo que, para variar, las criticas han sido acertadas ésta vez. Miles Morales agrega nuevas habilidades para dar un toque de novedad al juego, pero un par de poderes extra no hacen justicia a ésta secuela/spinoff. Los combos, movimientos, "trucos", son prácticamente los mismos de su primer parte. El gameplay es repetitivo hasta el cansancio, y el poco trabajado sistema de combate tampoco ayuda. Las misiones extras y coleccionables siguen siendo repetitivos y fastidiosos, nada nuevo por ahí. Miles, como personaje, está muy por debajo del carismático Peter. Incluso su sentido del humor, que pareciera que es calcado de Parker, se siente tosco y poco interesante. Es uno de esos personajes que no podemos esperar a que cierren la boca. Su historia es aburrida, sosa y con pocos "ganchos" para atraer nuestro interés.Por lo anterior, no encuentro ésta entrega precisamente divertida. Como punto positivo encontramos que las pantallas de carga son inexistentes, entre 1-2 segundos y ya estaremos jugando. GRÁFICOS:Al igual que su predecesor, es un espectáculo visual, pero en esta ocasión es con matices. .Al no haber grandes escenas nocturnas, queda desaprovechada la oportunidad de mostrar NYC, con un juego de luces y sombras, como sí lo hacía el primer juego. El nivel de detalle en las cinemáticas es increíble, pero la ciudad se ve un tanto por debajo de la calidad esperada (aunque yo culpo al clima nevoso que han decidido usar en esta entrega). No obstante, los detalles en la iluminación y la cantidad de partículas que se pueden apreciar en pantalla, especialmente durante las cinemáticas, son visualmente apantallantes. Los modelados del rostro de los personajes también han mejorado (no entraré en discusiones sobre los cambios en Peter...), y las permite lucirse mejor que el Marvel's Spider-Man, osea sí, todo lo contrario a los escenarios. SONIDO:La música sí que cambia totalmente. Menos heroico y mas acción. Al igual que con la entrega anterior, las canciones encajan de forma perfecta con lo que se está viendo en pantalla, aunque me han agradado un poco menos que las piezas usadas antes.Quedan con la personalidad de Miles, eso sí. INNOVACIÓN:Miles Morales agrega un par de añadidos, pero no son suficientes para que YO lo considere una evolución de algún tipo.Solo queda una duda, ¿Cómo harán los desarrolladores para no dejarnos estas mismas impresiones con Spider-Man 2?

Quite a short game, only maybe worth it if you get the 2 for 1 deal that includes the original game too (with all DLCs). And even then, puzzles and objectives are almost all based around the electricity power, Miles can completely remove tension during gameplay or cutscenes with his invisibility, you only get a few bossfights - including repeated or recycled ones. There's also just far less content there, and the writing does not make up for it sadly, as the most important section just comes down to misunderstanding/miscommunication and the villain gets redeemed instantly at the end. Honestly, Miles and his uncle were great, they could have carried a game on their own, but the writers wanted to focus a lot on social issues and non-issues, as well as put some political messages in prominent places in the game. The other characters were all odd and annoying, with a few exceptions. In a 60 hour game, tastefully spread out in the background, this would be fine, but in an 8 hour game where it's put front and center often, it's definitely intrusive. In a way, the game is mostly carried by being a follow-up to the previous one, using that as a background for the narrative and basis for the world and gameplay. It doesn't hold up on its own. I knew something was off when Pete got beaten by Rhino in the first act, even though he took down multiple super villains including Rhino in one night in the last game. They made him lose there so that Miles could get a big moment, which is great in concept - but come on, at least use a different villain where it makes sense for him to lose.

Spider-Man PS4 was a game that had the crowd going wild. Nevertheless, the game was awesome. 2 years later, its now Miles's turn to take the wheel while Peter hits the backseat in the spin off titleSpider-Man: Miles Morales. First off, we cant go too in depth without talking about the impact the PS5 brings to this game. With 4K graphics and two graphic options, the game just looks gorgeous. Playing on the butter smooth 60fps Performance Mode, or taking the other route and playing on Fidelity Mode, which drops the frame rate to 30fps, but makes up for that with the jaw dropping ray tracing. Either way, your getting the full next gen experience. Now, its story time. In this Spider-Man title, The veteran Spider- Man, Peter Parker, is taking a break and going away for two weeks to assist MJ in Symkaria, he then leaves Miles the task of being the only Spider-Man that NY will have. During this time, Miles discovers the Underground, a high tech organization that is going after Roxxon's new energy source, Nuform. Its now up to Miles to take the lead and discover the true motive of the Underground and put a stop to their movement, while finding out what it means to be his own version of Spider-Man. While the story has nice depth and meaning, its very short. People were completing the game in a day which isn't great for a game like Spider-Man. Most people worried about this game being a copy and paste version of Spider-Man PS4, however, it is far from that. The web-slinging has never felt better thanks to the DuelSense controller's adaptive triggers. The way Miles moves when swinging gives you the feel of a younger, mid experienced Spider-Man rather than Peter's older, veteran, Spider-Man. When Miles's web zips to a certain point, you can see him trying balance while landing. The little animations give you that "This is a different Spider-Man" feel. Miles's new bio electric Venom Power, Camouflage Power, and Gadgets, play a major change in combat when it comes to its heavy use in there respective scenarios. The skill tree gives a wide selection of new abilities too. The suits in the game are amazingly detailed, no matter how basic the suit looks. Each suit mod brings something special to the table, and yes, I'm looking at the Into the Spider-Verse suit mod. For future DLC, its safe to say we would all love to see more fan favorite suits come into the game. The photo mode in the game is so outstanding and easy to use just like in the first game. Pose Miles's in many different ways and use funny filters and stickers to create silly and cool photos, or use other graphical filters to recreate scenes from your favorite Spidey film or just make a badass photo in general. In all, Spider-Man: Miles Morales is a great way to show the power and potential of the PS5, however lacking in story length and bosses. Nevertheless, still also kicking off the new generation of gaming with other awesome titles.

The secondary villain is pretty generic but at least he's played well. My only big criticism is the redesign of Peter Parker's face. I liked the old design and not only does the new design make Peter look way younger than Miles, when he's supposed to be a mentor, but it looks too much like Tom Holland. It seems like Insomniac was trying to appeal to Marvel fans here when the old design was its own thing and didn't need changing. Still, this issue did not ruin my enjoyment of Spider-Man: Miles Morales, as it is a great game. It is a lot shorter than the first one but is still highly enjoyable.

Improves on Marvel's Spider-Man with stunning visuals (mind-blowing on PS5 performance mode), new abilities, and snappier puzzles. The game is short, yes, but it cuts out missions that people didn't really like in the previous game, like Mary Jane's investigative detours. It's also a nice length for casual gamers who are sick of open-world bloat— like the Assassin's Creed franchise— and I was able to 100% it in around 13 hours. Miles is a compelling character and I loved the focus on Harlem and its people. Spider-Man is no longer just about a web-slinger fighting villains of the week, but a hero looking out for the people of New York, the people who need it, and Miles provides a perfect opportunity for this. He helps out the working class, bodega owners, health-workers, people with disabilities— the diversity in this game is great. The game is a great addition to the growing Spider-Man Playstation franchise and I can't wait to play more.

This is an odd one to rate.  As far as gameplay goes, 10/10.  It picks up right where the original left off and advances things in interesting news ways with Miles’ venom powers.  Unfortunately, it also has to be noted that this is definitely not as full a game as the original.  It’s worthwhile on it’s own, and if it didn’t have to stand next to its big brother, it wouldn’t bother me a bit.  But it does stand next to it.  There are only a handful of meaningful boss fights and a more limited story, the rogues gallery is cut down to 3, and you only have two primary and one minor gang to worry about.  The city is there and it’s beautiful, but the scope of the game is noticeably smaller.  However, it also deserves mentioning that there’s little filler compared to th original and I think it benefits from that.  Side missions can be finished and collectibles rounded up before they wear out their welcome, and this is one of the first games in a while where I collected everything before I started yawning and decided to push on to the final mission.  Should it be full priced?  Maybe not.  But it’s a great game with an incredible vibe, and it’s an easy pickup once the price drops from retail.you just might not get as much time out of it as you expected, from the size of the first.

“Good things come in small packages.” Often some of the best treasures are found in the smallest places. That’s the way one feels after completing Spider-Man Miles Morales. An outstanding game, filled with heart, great storytelling, entertaining missions and just enough gameplay to keep you locked in. By the end, I simply wanted more! The great:The game is without a doubt a stand-alone superstar for the Spider-Man franchise. The character introduction and development is outstandingly engrossing. This game beats its predecessors with new combat and skills. The side-mission app: Friendly Neighborhood Spider-Man was unique and enjoyable. However, it would have been better if after competing the missions on the app more were added. The good:By the end of the main story the player has found themselves walking off a rollercoaster of ethical considerations. Motives aren’t always pure, and often we’re left to examine the whole picture without making snap overarching judgments of people and their lives. The player will find themselves disliking characters in one moment to sympathizing with their intents in the next. I enjoyed the rises, falls, and sacrifices of the main characters. The bad: Nothing really “bad” here, it’s an awesome game and should interest a wide range of gamers. However, if I had to pick one thing it would be as with the previous Spider-Man some of the side missions and crime-stopping grinding gets repetitive and boring. But the new combat system made up for the monotony with the wide range of abilities.

Marvel-Spider-man Miles Morales is a visual spectacle and for what it is worth, it's great. The scope of this game wasn't meant to be big, it was more of an expansion so wasn't meant to be a phenomenal game, however it shocked many reviewers.The Gameplay felt so much smoother than the previous Marvel Spiderman on the PS4, likely due to the superior mechanics encompassed in the Dualsense controller, and additionally, Miles has a variety of different attacks, including the Venom punch, venom smash and more. All these different attacks compliment each other and manifest to create a very strong combat system.The critically acclaimed Marvel Spider-man on the PS4 did have a few flaws, one being the repetitive missions and crimes; Miles Morales has truly improved upon this, adding innovative side missions in a wintery New York which leads to the next point: the graphics.This game on PS5 is gorgeous, the fidelity mode offers a native 4k resolution with reflections, ray-tracing and enhanced lighting effects and personally, this was the best mode. The performance mode and the Performance RT mode were more smooth with the higher frame rates but lacked the native 4k resolution and the other enhanced effects.The story was, again, good for what it was worth; it made the gamer resonate with the characters and the bonds created were very well crafted. Although, some parts were definitely rushed a bit. The game was on the short side, about 7 hours if you wanted to just blast through the story but the extensive activities around New York really added another layer to the game. Miles Morales was never expected to be a masterpiece and it delivered well in what it promised, innovative, non-repetitive combat, excellent web-swinging, great graphics, plenty of fun side missions and collectibles, but the pacing of the story did not help the game and some mechanics were not fully fleshed out., this is not to undermine how good the story was, some of it was truly amazing. Overall, a solid 8/10

For starters, the game is ridiculously too short. It clearly started as either an expansion to the first one that they repackaged as it's own game, or a rushed sequel that was cut way short in order to have a system seller for the PS5. On top of it being short, the story is also boring and predictable. I don't know if these characters are pulled from the comics, but compared to the first game, they are just....not good. Also, the wokeness is very real and very cringey. The seemingly out of nowhere, and ham-fisted, political scenes made me wonder how all the characters know that this Spider-Man is black. Is it because he wears a black costume? That seems rather racist. My only other criticism, and I know it's just a product of the world we live in now, is that it makes no sense that in a universe where Peter Parker is still alive and a mentor to Miles, that Miles calls himself Spider-Man. The game even seems to be aware of this, because there are numerous clumsy lines of dialogue trying to differentiate which Spider-Man a character is talking about. It would be the equivalent of having a Batman game where after Bruce trains up Dick Grayson, gives him his own bat suit, and then they just both call themselves Batman. It is unnecessarily confusing and stupid. Before I get into the game's strengths, it's important to point out that I loved the first game. In fact, it's the first and only game I've every platinumed. I played through it multiple times, beat it on the highest difficulty setting, and completed 100% of the DLC. Going into Miles Morales: Spiderman, I was worried that it would be too easy or feel too much like the original. I was wrong on both accounts. This game kicked my butt at first, and it was so much fun to learn all of Miles' new moves and unlock his new gadgets. I still think the fighting hologram gadget is lame, but everything else was a blast. I also really loved the fact that there were no forced stealth sections where you didn't play as Spider-Man or lame mini games that you have to do a dozen times. That alone was the biggest improvement over the first game. Speaking of improvements, this game looks, sounds, and feels way better.  It's clear that the developers really loved the first game they made and wanted to make everything feel familiar but better.  Also, the load times are amazing.  The sad truth is that if you were to take the characters and story of the first game and combine that with everything else from this game, it would probably be the perfect Spider-Man game. If you never played the first one, then the "Ultimate Launch Edition" is an easy recommend, since it comes with the first game remastered. If you've already played the first game and not interested in playing the remaster, than I would not recommend this one at full price. Wait for a sale.
